metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Describe Einstein's two postulates for his special theory of relativity that: the laws of physics are the same in all inertial (non-accelerated) frames of reference; the speed of light has a constant value for all observers regardless of their motion or the motion of the source

frame_of_reference.name: Frame of Reference
frame_of_reference.formula: A perspective from which measurements are made
frame_of_reference.correct: A frame of reference is a coordinate system from which we measure the relative location and motion of objects.

a fixed point in space.error: Too restrictive. Frames of reference can move.
a fixed point in space.fix: A frame of reference is any perspective from which measurements can be made, whether stationary or moving.
a fixed point in space.action: Consider: both a person on a train and a person on a platform are valid frames of reference.

the laboratory.error: Too specific. Any observer can define a frame of reference.
the laboratory.fix: A frame of reference is not limited to laboratories. Any observer, anywhere, defines their own frame.
the laboratory.action: Think of a frame as attached to any observer, whether in a car, spaceship, or standing still.

the universal rest frame.error: Einstein showed there is no universal rest frame.
the universal rest frame.fix: One of the key insights of relativity is that no frame is special. All inertial frames are equally valid.
the universal rest frame.action: Recall the Michelson-Morley experiment: they failed to find a preferred frame.

persistent.gap: You may be thinking of space as having a fixed background.
persistent.action: Remember: motion is always relative. There is no absolute 'at rest' in the universe.

inertial_frame_definition.name: Inertial Frame Definition
inertial_frame_definition.correct: An inertial frame of reference is one that is not accelerating, meaning it is either stationary or moving at constant velocity.

any frame at constant speed.error: Speed alone is not sufficient. Direction must also be constant.
any frame at constant speed.fix: Constant velocity means both constant speed AND constant direction. A car turning at constant speed is not inertial.
any frame at constant speed.action: Ask: is the frame changing velocity in any way? If yes, it's non-inertial.

only frames at rest.error: Too restrictive. Moving frames can be inertial if velocity is constant.
only frames at rest.fix: A train moving at constant velocity is an inertial frame, just like a stationary platform.
only frames at rest.action: Einstein's first postulate says physics works the same in ALL inertial frames, moving or stationary.

any non-rotating frame.error: Rotation is one type of acceleration, but linear acceleration also matters.
any non-rotating frame.fix: A non-inertial frame is ANY accelerating frame, whether accelerating linearly or rotating.
any non-rotating frame.action: Check for any change in velocity vector, not just rotation.

persistent.gap: You may be confusing speed with velocity.
persistent.action: Remember: velocity is a vector. Constant velocity means constant speed AND constant direction.

non_inertial_examples.name: Non-Inertial Frame Examples
non_inertial_examples.correct: Non-inertial frames include accelerating vehicles, rotating platforms, and any frame where velocity is changing.

a train at constant speed on curved trac.error: Curved motion involves centripetal acceleration, even at constant speed.
a train at constant speed on curved trac.fix: Going around a curve changes the direction of velocity, which is acceleration.
a train at constant speed on curved trac.action: Identify examples: car turning a corner, satellite in orbit, person on merry-go-round.

a rocket coasting in space.error: A coasting rocket has constant velocity and is actually inertial.
a rocket coasting in space.fix: If the engines are off and the rocket moves at constant velocity, it's an inertial frame.
a rocket coasting in space.action: The key question is: is the velocity changing? Coasting = no acceleration = inertial.

Earth's surface.error: Technically correct but treated as approximately inertial for VCE.
Earth's surface.fix: Earth rotates, so it's strictly non-inertial. For VCE, we approximate it as inertial.
Earth's surface.action: Know that Earth is technically non-inertial but treated as inertial for most problems.

persistent.gap: You may be forgetting that changing direction is also acceleration.
persistent.action: Acceleration = any change in velocity. This includes speeding up, slowing down, or turning.

first_postulate_statement.name: First Postulate Statement
first_postulate_statement.formula: Laws of physics are the same in all inertial frames
first_postulate_statement.correct: Einstein's first postulate states that the laws of physics are the same in all inertial frames of reference.

laws of physics are the same in all fram.error: Missing the crucial word 'inertial'. Non-inertial frames have different physics.
laws of physics are the same in all fram.fix: The postulate applies only to inertial frames. In accelerating frames, pseudo-forces appear.
laws of physics are the same in all fram.action: Try dropping a ball in an accelerating car versus a constant-velocity train. Different results.

laws of physics are different for moving.error: Opposite of what the postulate says.
laws of physics are different for moving.fix: The first postulate says physics is the SAME for all inertial observers, moving or stationary.
laws of physics are different for moving.action: You cannot detect motion by doing physics experiments in a closed room.

the speed of light is constant.error: That's the second postulate, not the first.
the speed of light is constant.fix: First postulate: laws of physics are the same. Second postulate: speed of light is constant.
the speed of light is constant.action: Keep the two postulates distinct. They are separate statements that together form special relativity.

persistent.gap: You may be confusing the two postulates.
persistent.action: First postulate: laws are the same. Second postulate: c is constant. Memorise both separately.

first_postulate_consequence.name: First Postulate Consequences
first_postulate_consequence.formula: No experiment can detect absolute motion
first_postulate_consequence.correct: A consequence of the first postulate is that no physics experiment performed inside a closed room can determine if you are moving at constant velocity or stationary.

experiments give different results in di.error: Opposite of what the postulate implies.
experiments give different results in di.fix: The first postulate says experiments give the SAME results in all inertial frames.
experiments give different results in di.action: Drop a ball on a smooth train versus on a platform. It falls the same way.

you can detect motion by measuring time.error: Time passes the same way in your own frame.
you can detect motion by measuring time.fix: You cannot detect your own motion. Time dilation is observed when comparing DIFFERENT frames.
you can detect motion by measuring time.action: Your clock ticks normally for you, regardless of your motion.

motion creates observable forces.error: Constant velocity motion creates no forces. Only acceleration does.
motion creates observable forces.fix: In an inertial frame moving at constant velocity, there are no forces due to the motion itself.
motion creates observable forces.action: You don't feel motion on a smooth train until it accelerates or brakes.

persistent.gap: You may be thinking of acceleration effects, not constant velocity.
persistent.action: Remember: constant velocity produces no detectable effects. Only acceleration does.

second_postulate_statement.name: Second Postulate Statement
second_postulate_statement.correct: Einstein's second postulate states that the speed of light in a vacuum is the same for all observers, regardless of their motion or the motion of the light source.

speed of light depends on the source's m.error: Classical physics prediction. Contradicted by experiment.
speed of light depends on the source's m.fix: The source's motion does not affect light speed. A moving flashlight emits light at c, not c + v.
speed of light depends on the source's m.action: This is counterintuitive but confirmed by the Michelson-Morley experiment.

speed of light is constant only for stat.error: Missing the key insight. c is constant for ALL observers.
speed of light is constant only for stat.fix: Whether you're moving toward or away from light, you still measure its speed as c.
speed of light is constant only for stat.action: Both police officers in a chase measure a laser beam at exactly c.

speed of light adds to observer's veloci.error: This is the classical prediction, not relativity.
speed of light adds to observer's veloci.fix: Light doesn't follow classical velocity addition. c + v = c in relativity.
speed of light adds to observer's veloci.action: Classical physics says light from an approaching source should be faster. It's not.

persistent.gap: You're applying everyday intuition about velocities to light.
persistent.action: Accept that light is special. Its speed is c for everyone, always, in vacuum.

second_postulate_consequence.name: Second Postulate Consequences
second_postulate_consequence.formula: Space and time must be relative
second_postulate_consequence.correct: Because c is constant for all observers, space and time cannot be absolute. Different observers measure different lengths and time intervals.

space and time are absolute.error: This is the classical view that Einstein overturned.
space and time are absolute.fix: For c to be constant for all observers, length and time must vary between frames.
space and time are absolute.action: If speed = distance/time and c is constant, then distance and time must adjust.

only time is relative, space is absolute.error: Both space and time are relative in special relativity.
only time is relative, space is absolute.fix: Time dilation and length contraction are both consequences of constant c.
only time is relative, space is absolute.action: Learn about length contraction alongside time dilation.

the second postulate has no observable e.error: It has profound effects, including time dilation and length contraction.
the second postulate has no observable e.fix: The constant speed of light leads to measurable effects in GPS systems and particle accelerators.
the second postulate has no observable e.action: GPS satellites must correct for relativistic time differences.

persistent.gap: You may not understand why constant c leads to relative space and time.
persistent.action: Think: if c = distance/time is fixed, and observers disagree on distances, they must also disagree on times.

michelson_morley_purpose.name: Michelson-Morley Experiment Purpose
michelson_morley_purpose.correct: The Michelson-Morley experiment attempted to detect Earth's motion through the hypothetical luminiferous aether by measuring changes in the speed of light.

to measure the speed of light.error: The speed of light was already known. They were looking for variations.
to measure the speed of light.fix: They wanted to detect CHANGES in light speed due to Earth's motion through the aether.
to measure the speed of light.action: The experiment compared light speeds in perpendicular directions.

to prove Einstein's theory.error: The experiment was done before Einstein's theory (1887 vs 1905).
to prove Einstein's theory.fix: The experiment was designed to find the aether. Its null result later supported Einstein.

to measure length contraction.error: Length contraction wasn't known when the experiment was designed.
to measure length contraction.fix: They expected to find a difference in light speeds due to the aether wind.
to measure length contraction.action: The null result was surprising at the time and needed explanation.

persistent.gap: You may be confusing the experiment's original purpose with its later significance.
persistent.action: Remember: they expected to find the aether. The null result was unexpected.

michelson_morley_result.name: Michelson-Morley Null Result
michelson_morley_result.formula: No change in light speed detected
michelson_morley_result.correct: The Michelson-Morley experiment found no change in the speed of light regardless of direction or Earth's motion. This null result supported Einstein's second postulate.

detected the aether.error: Opposite of what happened. They found no evidence of the aether.
detected the aether.fix: The experiment's null result suggested the aether does not exist.
detected the aether.action: If the aether existed, they would have measured different light speeds in different directions.

showed light travels at different speeds.error: They found light speed was constant in all directions.
showed light travels at different speeds.fix: No matter how they oriented the experiment, light speed was always c.
showed light travels at different speeds.action: This constancy of c is exactly what the second postulate describes.

proved relativity wrong.error: Opposite. The null result supports relativity.
proved relativity wrong.fix: The constant speed of light, found by Michelson-Morley, is the basis of the second postulate.
proved relativity wrong.action: The experiment provides evidence FOR Einstein's relativity, not against it.

persistent.gap: You may be confusing what they expected to find with what they actually found.
persistent.action: Expected: aether wind affecting light. Found: no effect. Conclusion: no aether, c is constant.

classical_vs_relativity_velocities.name: Velocity Addition Comparison
classical_vs_relativity_velocities.formula: Classical: v₁ + v₂; Relativity: different at high speeds
classical_vs_relativity_velocities.correct: Classical physics predicts velocities add linearly, so light from a moving source should travel faster. Relativity says c is always c, regardless of source motion.

both predict the same results.error: They make different predictions at high speeds.
both predict the same results.fix: At everyday speeds, the difference is negligible. At speeds near c, they differ significantly.
both predict the same results.action: Compare: classical predicts c + v for light from a moving source. Relativity predicts c.

relativity predicts faster-than-light tr.fix: Nothing with mass can reach c. Velocities never add to exceed c in relativity.
relativity predicts faster-than-light tr.action: Even 0.9c + 0.9c doesn't equal 1.8c in relativity. The result is about 0.99c.

classical physics is always wrong.error: Classical physics works well at low speeds.
classical physics is always wrong.fix: For everyday speeds (v << c), classical and relativistic predictions are nearly identical.
classical physics is always wrong.action: Relativity reduces to classical physics at low speeds. It's a refinement, not a replacement.

persistent.gap: You may not understand when classical and relativistic predictions differ.
persistent.action: Remember: differences become significant only at speeds approaching c.

classical_vs_relativity_space_time.name: Space and Time Comparison
classical_vs_relativity_space_time.correct: Classical physics assumes space and time are absolute and the same for all observers. Relativity says they depend on the observer's frame of reference.

both treat space and time the same way.error: This is a fundamental difference between them.
both treat space and time the same way.fix: Classical: everyone agrees on lengths and times. Relativity: observers can disagree.
both treat space and time the same way.action: In relativity, moving clocks run slow and moving objects contract.

relativity says time is absolute.error: Opposite. Time is relative in special relativity.
relativity says time is absolute.fix: Different observers can measure different time intervals between the same events.
relativity says time is absolute.action: This is called time dilation and has been confirmed experimentally.

classical physics accounts for time dila.error: Time dilation is purely a relativistic effect.
classical physics accounts for time dila.fix: In classical physics, a second is a second for everyone. Relativity shows this is only approximate.
classical physics accounts for time dila.action: Time dilation was unknown before Einstein and contradicts classical assumptions.

persistent.gap: You may not grasp how revolutionary the idea of relative time was.
persistent.action: Before Einstein, everyone assumed clocks tick at the same rate everywhere. Einstein showed otherwise.
